name: Memory & Storage
description: Explore primary and secondary storage, memory hierarchy, and data representation

questions.question_text: Convert the denary number 13 to binary.
Convert the binary number 00101101 to denary.
Convert the denary number 255 to hexadecimal.
questions.model_answer: FF

questions.question_text: Convert the hexadecimal number A2 to denary.
Convert the binary number 11110000 to hexadecimal.
questions.model_answer: F0

questions.question_text: Convert the hexadecimal number 3C to binary.
Give the binary equivalent of the hexadecimal value 7E.
Write the hexadecimal equivalent of the binary number 11010101.
questions.model_answer: D5

questions.question_text: Perform a binary left shift by 2 places on the binary number 00101100.
What is the result of performing a binary right shift by 3 on 11010000?
Add the binary numbers 01010101 and 00001111.
What is 11110000 + 00001111 in binary?
A binary number is shifted left by one place. Describe the effect on the value of the number.
questions.model_answer: The value is doubled.

questions.question_text: A binary number is shifted right by two places. Describe the effect on the value of the number.
questions.model_answer: The value is divided by 4.

questions.question_text: State the purpose of secondary storage in a computer system.
questions.model_answer: To store data and files long-term, even when the computer is turned off.

questions.question_text: Give two examples of secondary storage devices.
questions.model_answer: Hard disk drive (HDD), Solid-state drive (SSD), USB flash drive, SD card, Optical disc (any two)

questions.question_text: State one advantage of using a solid-state drive instead of a hard disk drive.
questions.model_answer: Faster data access speeds / No moving parts so less likely to break / Uses less power

questions.question_text: Give one reason why an optical disc might be chosen for storing data.
questions.model_answer: It is cheap to produce / Portable / Good for distributing media like films or games

questions.question_text: State one drawback of using magnetic storage.
questions.model_answer: It has moving parts that can wear out / Slower access speed / More likely to be damaged if dropped

questions.question_text: Explain why cloud storage is sometimes considered a form of secondary storage.
questions.model_answer: It stores data permanently but on remote servers, not directly inside the computer.

questions.question_text: Give two types of secondary storage.
questions.model_answer: Magnetic, Solid state, Optical (any two)

questions.question_text: Explain why a computer needs both RAM and ROM.
questions.model_answer: ROM contains the instructions needed to start the computer. RAM is used to store programs and data while they are in use.

questions.question_text: Give one reason why RAM is important in a computer system.
questions.model_answer: It temporarily stores data and instructions for programs currently being used.

questions.question_text: What type of data is stored in ROM?
questions.model_answer: Permanent data such as the BIOS or startup instructions.

questions.question_text: State the main difference between RAM and ROM.
questions.model_answer: RAM is volatile and loses its contents when the power is off. ROM is non-volatile and keeps its data permanently.

questions.question_text: Name two types of primary storage.
questions.model_answer: RAM and ROM

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of file compression?
questions.model_answer: To reduce the size of a file so it takes up less storage space and can be transferred more quickly.

questions.question_text: State two benefits of compressing a file.
questions.model_answer: Takes up less storage space, transfers faster, reads/writes quicker (any two).

questions.question_text: What happens to data that is removed during lossy compression?
questions.model_answer: It is permanently deleted and cannot be recovered.

questions.question_text: Give one advantage of using lossy compression.
questions.model_answer: It reduces file size more than lossless storage.

questions.question_text: Give one disadvantage of lossy compression.
questions.model_answer: Data is permanently lost and the file cannot be restored to its original form.

questions.question_text: Explain one reason why a programmer would use lossless compression instead of lossy compression.
questions.model_answer: Lossless keeps all data, which is important for files that must remain unchanged, like programs or text documents.

questions.question_text: What type of files is lossy compression best suited for?
questions.model_answer: Images, audio, and video files where some loss of quality is acceptable.

questions.question_text: State one file type where lossless compression should be used and explain why.
questions.model_answer: Executable files, because removing any data could stop the program from working correctly.

questions.question_text: Explain how characters are stored in a computer system.
questions.model_answer: Each character is stored as a binary number using a character set such as ASCII or Unicode.

questions.question_text: Explain why lossless compression is used instead of lossy compression for text files.
questions.model_answer: Lossless compression keeps all the original data, which is important for text files because removing any data could change the meaning of the conten or corrupt the file.

questions.question_text: State what an image is made up of when stored in a computer.
questions.model_answer: A grid of pixels, each with its own binary value representing colour.

questions.question_text: What is meant by the term 'resolution' in relation to digital images?
questions.model_answer: The number of pixels in an image, usually given as width × height.

questions.question_text: What is meant by 'colour depth' in a digital image?
questions.model_answer: The number of bits used to represent the colour of each pixel.

questions.question_text: Explain how increasing the colour depth of an image affects the file size.
questions.model_answer: More bits are needed for each pixel, so the file size increases.

questions.question_text: Give one example of metadata stored with an image file.
questions.model_answer: Image width, height, colour depth, file format, or author (any one).

questions.question_text: An image is 100 pixels wide and 50 pixels tall. Each pixel uses 8 bits. Calculate the file size in bytes (ignore metadata).
An image has a resolution of 200 × 100 pixels and a colour depth of 16 bits. Calculate the file size in kilobytes (ignore metadata).
Describe how to calculate the file size of a bitmap image.
questions.model_answer: Multiply width × height × colour depth (in bits), then divide by 8 to get bytes.

questions.question_text: An image is 100 × 100 pixels with a colour depth of 24 bits. Estimate the file size in kilobytes (ignore metadata).
Explain how sound is stored in a computer.
questions.model_answer: Sound is sampled at regular intervals and each sample is stored as a binary value.

questions.question_text: What is meant by the term 'sample rate'?
questions.model_answer: The number of samples taken per second, measured in Hertz (Hz).

questions.question_text: What is meant by 'bit depth' in sound recording?
questions.model_answer: The number of bits used to store each sound sample.

questions.question_text: How does increasing the sample rate affect the quality and file size of a sound file?
questions.model_answer: It improves sound quality but increases the file size.

questions.question_text: A sound file is sampled at 10,000 samples per second, using 8 bits per sample. It lasts for 2 seconds. Calculate the file size in bytes (ignore metadata).
A school wants to back up all of its computers at the end of each week. Which type of storage would be most suitable and why?
questions.model_answer: Magnetic storage, such as a hard disk or tape, because it has a high capacity and low cost per GB.

questions.question_text: A photographer wants to store photos on a small, portable device while travelling. Which storage type is most suitable and why?
questions.model_answer: Solid state storage, such as a USB drive or SD card, because it is lightweight, durable, and portable.

questions.question_text: A company needs to distribute video tutorials to customers. The data must be cheap to produce and readable by most computers. Which storage type is best?
questions.model_answer: Optical storage, like DVDs, because it is cheap to produce and widely compatible.

questions.question_text: A video editor is working with large files and needs fast access speeds and high reliability. Which storage type should they choose?
questions.model_answer: Solid state storage, like an SSD, because it is fast and reliable with no moving parts.

questions.question_text: State one reason why magnetic storage is often used in desktop computers.
questions.model_answer: It offers high capacity at a low cost per GB.

questions.question_text: A smartphone is an embedded system that needs fast access to apps and files. What type of storage does it use and why?
questions.model_answer: Solid state storage, because it is fast, reliable, and compact — ideal for portable devices like smartphones.

questions.question_text: A smart TV streams and stores shows temporarily. Which type of storage is most suitable and why?
questions.model_answer: Solid state storage, as it is quiet, reliable, and offers fast access speeds suitable for streaming and buffering.

questions.question_text: A digital camera is used to store high-quality images on a removable storage device. Which type of storage is used and why?
questions.model_answer: Solid state storage, such as an SD card, because it is portable, durable, and has no moving parts.

questions.question_text: A car sat nav system stores maps and regularly reads location data. Which storage type is most suitable?
questions.model_answer: Solid state storage, because it is reliable, has fast read speeds, and can cope with movement and vibrations in a vehicle.

questions.question_text: A games console needs storage to load games quickly and save user progress. Which type of storage is best and why?
questions.model_answer: Solid state storage (SSD), as it has fast access times for loading games and is more reliable than magnetic storage plus it has no moving parts and is quieter.

questions.question_text: Put the following units in order from smallest to largest: megabyte, bit, kilobyte, byte.
questions.model_answer: Bit, byte, kilobyte, megabyte

questions.question_text: How many bytes are there in a kilobyte?
questions.model_answer: 1,000 bytes (as per base 10 unit used in OCR GCSE)

questions.question_text: A file is 3 megabytes in size. How many kilobytes is this?
questions.model_answer: 3,000 kilobytes

questions.question_text: State the most appropriate unit for measuring the size of a high-definition video file.
questions.model_answer: Gigabyte

questions.question_text: Explain why computers store data in binary.
questions.model_answer: Because computers use electrical circuits that have two states — on and off — which match the 1s and 0s in binary.

questions.question_text: State the number of bits in a byte.
A file contains the string 'Hello'. How many bytes are needed to store this text using ASCII?
questions.model_answer: 5 bytes, because each ASCII character uses 1 byte and there are 5 characters.

questions.question_text: How many bits are needed to store a 10-character password using ASCII?
A string contains 4 characters and is stored using Unicode (16-bit). How many bytes are needed?
A student says that 1 character always equals 1 bit. Explain why this is incorrect.
questions.model_answer: A character usually takes 8 bits (1 byte) in ASCII. 1 bit can only store 2 values — not enough for characters.

questions.question_text: A word processor document contains 1,000 characters. Estimate the file size in bytes using ASCII.
questions.model_answer: 1,000 characters × 1 byte = 1,000 bytes

questions.question_text: A string contains 4 characters and is stored using Unicode (16-bit). How many bytes are needed?
State what is typically stored in RAM.
questions.model_answer: Data and programs that are currently in use by the computer.

questions.question_text: What is usually stored in ROM?
questions.model_answer: Startup instructions like the BIOS needed to boot the system.

questions.question_text: Give one example of what might be stored in ROM in a smart TV.
questions.model_answer: The firmware or startup software that controls how the TV operates.

questions.question_text: Give one example of data that might be stored in RAM in a smartphone.
questions.model_answer: An app that is currently open or being used.

questions.question_text: Give one example of what ROM is used for in an embedded system like a washing machine.
questions.model_answer: To store the fixed program that controls the wash cycle options.

questions.question_text: A games console has both RAM and ROM. Explain the use of each.
questions.model_answer: ROM stores the startup software. RAM stores the game and data currently being used during play.

questions.question_text: Give one reason why RAM is important in a computer.
questions.model_answer: It allows the CPU to quickly access data from currently running programs.
